info.document:
Editor: David Clarke         + 44 207 542 7923
Picture Desk: Singapore         + 65 6870 3775
Graphics queries:                + 65 6870 3595

(All times GMT/ET)
TOP STORIES
North Korea seeks military 'equilibrium' with United States
SEOUL/UNITED NATIONS - North Korea aims to reach an
"equilibrium" of military force with the United States, which
signaled its patience for diplomacy is wearing thin after
Pyongyang fired a missile over Japan for the second time in
under a month. (NORTHKOREA-MISSILES/ (WRAPUP 2, PIX, TV,
GRAPHIC), moved, by Christine Kim and Michelle Nichols, 1,000
words)
+ See also:
- NORTHKOREA-MISSILES/CHINA-DIPLOMACY (UPDATE 1), moved, 340
words

British police arrest 18-year-old in hunt for London bombers
LONDON - British police hunting those behind a bomb which
injured 29 people on a London train on Friday arrest an
18-year-old man in a move described as significant.
(BRITAIN-SECURITY/LONDON (UPDATE 1, TV, PIX), expect by 1100, by
Kate Holton, 500 words)

Clashes in St Louis as ex-cop cleared of murdering black man
ST. LOUIS - Police fire tear gas and rubber bullets in
clashes with demonstrators in St Louis after a white former
policeman was acquitted of murdering a black suspect.
(MISSOURI-CRIME/ (UPDATE 2, PIX, TV), by Valerie Volcovici and
Kenny Bahr, 570 words)
+ See also:
- MISSOURI-CRIME/JUDGE, moved, by Chris Kenning, 580 words

Bangladesh warns Myanmar over border amid refugee crisis
DHAKA - Bangladesh accuses Myanmar of repeatedly violating
its air space and warns that any more "provocative acts" could
have "unwarranted consequences", raising the risk of a
deterioration in relations already strained by the Rohingya
refugee crisis. (MYANMAR-ROHINGYA/ (UPDATE 2, PIX, TV, GRAPHIC),
moved, by Ruma Paul, 750 words)
+ See also:
MYANMAR-ROHINGYA/BANGLADESH-IMAGE (PIX), moved, 300 words

UNITED STATES
Trump to 'slap' foes, embrace friends in U.N. speech - envoy
WASHINGTON - U.S. President Donald Trump will pummel foes
and embrace friends in his first speech to U.N. General Assembly
next week, keeping pressure on Washington's adversaries North
Korea and Iran, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley says.
(UN-ASSEMBLY/TRUMP (PIX, TV), moved, by Jeff Mason and Roberta
Rampton, 340 words)
About 1.5 million without power in Irma's wake
MIAMI - About 1.5 million homes and businesses in Florida
and Georgia remain without power after Hurricane Irma, including
46 of Florida's nearly 700 nursing homes caught in the deadly
storm's path. (STORM-IRMA/ (UPDATE 2, PIX, TV), moved, by
Zachary Fagenson, 525 words)
+ See also:
-     STORM-IRMA/POWER-OUTAGES (FACTBOX), moved, 440 words

MIDDLE EAST
Iraq's Kurdish parliament backs Sept 25 independence vote
ERBIL, Iraq - Parliament of Iraq's autonomous Kurdistan
region approves plan to conduct referendum on independence Sept.
25, ignoring opposition from Baghdad and wider region as well as
Western concerns that vote could spark fresh conflict.
(MIDEAST-CRISIS/IRAQ-KURDS-VOTE (UPDATE 4, TV, PIX), moved, by
Raya Jalabi, 650 words)
EUROPE
Tax perks tempt Italian bankers back to la dolce vita
LONDON/MILAN - Italian financiers who handle some of their
country's biggest deals out of London are moving to Milan, lured
by bumper tax breaks at a time of deep uncertainty about Brexit,
sources familiar with the plans said. (BRITAIN-EU/ITALY (REPEAT,
PIX), by Pamela Barbaglia and Stephen Jewkes, 950 words)

AFRICA
Congo security forces kill Burundian refugees - sources
KINSHASA - Congolese security forces kill at least 18
Burundian refugees during clashes over plans to send some of
them home, local activists and a diplomatic source say.
(CONGO-BURUNDI/REFUGEES (UPDATE 2, TV), expect by 1100, 300
words)

KPMG's South Africa bosses purged over Gupta scandal
JOHANNESBURG - Global auditor KPMG clears out its South
African leadership en masse after damning findings from
internal investigation into work done for businessmen friends of
President Jacob Zuma. (KPMG-SAFRICA/ (UPDATE 5, PIX, TV), moved,
by Ed Cropley and Joe Brock, 750 words)

AMERICAS
Canada sought to resolve Boeing trade disputes at meeting
OTTAWA/MONTREAL - Canada last month attempted to end
deepening dispute with Boeing by suggesting it could withdraw
threat not to buy Super Hornet jets if U.S. firm dropped trade
challenge against Canadian planemaker Bombardier, three people
with knowledge of matter tell Reuters. (BOEING-BOMBARDIER/CANADA
(EXCLUSIVE, UPDATE 1, PIX), moved, by David Ljunggren and
Allison Lampert, 540 words)

ASIA
Pakistan army pushes political role for militant-linked
groups
LAHORE, Pakistan - New Pakistani political party controlled
by an Islamist with a $10 million U.S. bounty on his head is
backing a candidate in a by-election on Sunday, in what a former
senior army officer says is a key step in a military-proposed
plan to mainstream militant groups. (PAKISTAN-POLITICS/MILITANTS
(TV, PIX), moved, by Asif Shahzad, 1,085 words)

"Wolf of Wall Street" producer settles U.S. lawsuit
KUALA LUMPUR - Movie company that made "The Wolf of Wall
Street", and was co-founded by Malaysian prime minister's step
son, settles civil lawsuit brought by U.S. government to seize
assets allegedly bought with money stolen from Malaysian state
fund. (MALAYSIA-SCANDAL/REDGRANITE, moved, 400 words)

SPACE
Cassini ends 13-year odyssey with fiery plunge into Saturn
U.S. space agency NASA receives final signal from its
Cassini spacecraft as it ends ground-breaking, 13-year Saturn
mission with meteor-like plunge into ringed planet's atmosphere.
(SPACE-SATURN/CASSINI (UPDATE 3, PIX, TV), moved, by Ian
Simpson, 500 words)
